meanings.def: to take hold of something and use force in order to move it or try to move it towards yourself
examples: You push and I'll pull.
Don't pull so hard or the handle will come off.
He got hold of the end and pulled.
pull on something I pulled on the rope to see if it was secure.
pull at something He pulled at her coat sleeve.
pull something Stop pulling her hair!
She pulled the cord and the parachute opened.
pull somebody/something + adv./prep. She pulled him gently towards her.
He smiled and pulled her closer.
pull something + adj. Pull the door shut.
She pulled the straps tight.

meanings.def: to remove something from a place by pulling
examples: pull something If these weeds are not pulled, they will spread rapidly .
He pulled a knife and stabbed the man.
pull something + adv./prep. Pull the plug out.
to pull out a gun/knife
She pulled off her boots.
James pulled his shirt over his head, letting it fall to the floor.
They were still pulling bodies from the rubble.
She he was spotted in the water and pulled to safety.
He pulled a gun on me (= took out a gun and aimed it at me).
Alison pulled the little dog out of the water.
I pulled the letter out of my pocket.

meanings.def: to move somebody/something in a particular direction by pulling
examples: Pull your chair nearer the table.
I pulled up a seat next to her.
He pulled on his sweater.
She took his arm and pulled him along.
The sun was too bright so I pulled the blinds down.
Mary pulled the blanket up over her head.
He was the only living person pulled from the rubble that night .
She pulled on her boots and hurried off.

meanings.def: to hold or be attached to something and move it along behind you
examples: In this area oxen are used to pull carts.
a car pulling a trailer
The horses pulling the wagon stopped suddenly.
Ponies were used to pull the coal trucks.
Pull the chair nearer the table.
They use oxen to pull their carts.
The sack is too heavy to lift—you’ll have to drag it.
I drew my chair closer to the fire.
a horse-drawn carriage
Fishermen were hauling in their nets.
Our car was towed away by the police.
She tried to escape but he tugged her back.

meanings.def: to move your body or a part of your body in a particular direction, especially using force
examples: + adv./prep. He tried to kiss her but she pulled away.
pull something/yourself + adv./prep. The dog snapped at her and she quickly pulled back her hand.
pull something/yourself + adj. John pulled himself free and ran off.

meanings.def: to open or close curtains, etc.
examples: Pull the curtains—it's dark outside.

meanings.def: to damage a muscle, etc. by using too much force
examples: to pull a muscle/ligament/tendon
He pulled a hamstring in training.
He injured his knee playing hockey.
Three people were injured in the crash.
50 people were seriously wounded in the attack.
Did you hurt yourself?
Don’t strain your eyes by reading in poor light.
He pulled a muscle in his back.
She has pulled her Achilles tendon.

meanings.def: to move a switch, etc. towards yourself or down in order to operate a machine or piece of equipment
examples: Pull the lever to start the motor.
Don't pull the trigger!

meanings.def: to move or make a vehicle move to the side
examples: The wheel is pulling to the left.
She pulled the car to the right to avoid the dog.

meanings.def: to work hard and use a lot of power
examples: The old car pulled hard as we drove slowly up the hill.

meanings.def: to use oars to move a boat along
examples: They pulled towards the shore.

meanings.def: to attract the interest or support of somebody/something
examples: They pulled in huge crowds on their latest tour.

meanings.def: to attract somebody sexually and get them to spend the evening with you
examples: He can still pull the girls.
She's hoping to pull tonight.

meanings.def: to succeed in playing a trick on somebody, committing a crime, etc.
examples: He's pulling some sort of trick on you.

meanings.def: to cancel an event; to stop showing an advertisement, etc.
examples: The gig was pulled at the last moment.

meanings.def: to perform two roles or functions at the same time
examples: This device can pull double duty as a decent laptop and an adequate tablet.
She deserves credit for serving double duty as a host and performer.

meanings.def: to start being more careful in your behaviour, especially by spending less money than before
examples: Small businesses have had to pull their horns in during the recession.

meanings.def: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something
examples: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

meanings.def: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely
to improve your situation yourself, without help from other people
to produce an expression on your face to show that you do not like somebody/something or in order to make somebody laugh
examples: What are you pulling a face at now?
Do you think it’s funny to make faces behind my back?
She made a disgusted face at that and walked away.
She made a funny face and gave a snorting sort of laugh.

meanings.def: to trick somebody
to have different aims that cannot be achieved together without causing problems
examples: There are different considerations, often pulling in different directions.

meanings.def: to succeed in doing something difficult by making an extra effort or doing something clever or surprising
examples: We managed to pull it out of the bag despite not being at our best for most of the game.

meanings.def: to play a joke on somebody, usually by making them believe something that is not true
used to show that you do not believe what somebody has just said
to make the greatest effort possible to achieve something
to put an end to somebody’s project, a plan, etc.
examples: The television company pulled the plug on the series after only five episodes.
They decided to pull the plug on the project.

meanings.def: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody
examples: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

meanings.def: to suddenly produce something as a solution to a problem
to make use of your place or status in society or at work to make somebody do what you want
to take help or support away from somebody suddenly
to try to improve your performance, work, behaviour, etc.
examples: You're going to have to pull your socks up.

meanings.def: to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody
to control events or the actions of other people
to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He pulled up stakes and went back to France.

meanings.def: to work as hard as everyone else in a job, an activity, etc.
to hide your real actions or intentions from somebody by making them believe something that is not true

idioms.def: to perform two roles or functions at the same time
examples: This device can pull double duty as a decent laptop and an adequate tablet.
She deserves credit for serving double duty as a host and performer.

idioms.def: to start being more careful in your behaviour, especially by spending less money than before
examples: Small businesses have had to pull their horns in during the recession.

idioms.def: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something
examples: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

idioms.def: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely

idioms.idiom: pull/drag yourself up by your (own) bootstraps
idioms.def: to improve your situation yourself, without help from other people
to produce an expression on your face to show that you do not like somebody/something or in order to make somebody laugh
examples: What are you pulling a face at now?
Do you think it’s funny to make faces behind my back?
She made a disgusted face at that and walked away.
She made a funny face and gave a snorting sort of laugh.

idioms.def: to trick somebody
to have different aims that cannot be achieved together without causing problems
examples: There are different considerations, often pulling in different directions.

idioms.idiom: pull it/something out of the bag
idioms.def: to succeed in doing something difficult by making an extra effort or doing something clever or surprising
examples: We managed to pull it out of the bag despite not being at our best for most of the game.

idioms.def: to play a joke on somebody, usually by making them believe something that is not true

idioms.idiom: pull the other one (—it’s got bells on)
idioms.def: used to show that you do not believe what somebody has just said
to make the greatest effort possible to achieve something
to put an end to somebody’s project, a plan, etc.
examples: The television company pulled the plug on the series after only five episodes.
They decided to pull the plug on the project.

idioms.def: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody
examples: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

idioms.idiom: pull something/a rabbit out of the hat
idioms.def: to suddenly produce something as a solution to a problem
to make use of your place or status in society or at work to make somebody do what you want

idioms.idiom: pull the rug (out) from under somebody’s feet
idioms.def: to take help or support away from somebody suddenly
to try to improve your performance, work, behaviour, etc.
examples: You're going to have to pull your socks up.

idioms.def: to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody
to control events or the actions of other people
to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He pulled up stakes and went back to France.

idioms.def: to work as hard as everyone else in a job, an activity, etc.

idioms.idiom: pull the wool over somebody’s eyes
idioms.def: to hide your real actions or intentions from somebody by making them believe something that is not true

meanings.def: an act of trying to make something move by taking hold of it and using force to bring it towards you
examples: I gave the door a sharp pull and it opened.
One last pull on the rope should do it.

meanings.def: a strong physical force that makes something move in a particular direction
examples: the earth’s gravitational pull
The tides depend on the pull of the moon.

meanings.def: the fact of something attracting you or having a strong effect on you
examples: The magnetic pull of the city was hard to resist.
He felt the pull of paternal love.
She felt the pull of her homeland.
It is hard to deny the emotional pull of this music.

meanings.def: power and influence over other people
examples: people who have a lot of pull with the media

meanings.def: an act of taking a deep breath of smoke from a cigarette, etc. or a deep drink of something
examples: She took a long pull on her cigarette.
a pull at his flask

meanings.def: a difficult walk up a steep hill
examples: It's a long pull up to the summit.

meanings.def: an injury to a muscle caused by using too much force
something such as a handle or rope that you use to pull something
examples: a bell/door pull

meanings.def: trying to find a sexual partner

idioms.def: trying to find a sexual partner
